Description: Fragmentary rectangular plaque, or scaraboid, carved from stone, probably steatite; both sides bear an incised decoration surrounded by a rope border; on upper side, plumed cartouche (or oval?) probably containing the name of Menkheperra (only sun-disc and men-sign preserved); on underside, geometric pattern consisting of central twisted ribbon with raised cobra symmetrically arranged in lateral fields; lower half broken off.
Curator's comments: Scaraboid/plaque not yet located, published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 156). Two other rectangular plaques were discovered in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 157-158). Only one - BM 1888,0601.71 - has so far been located and it is a convex one. According to B. Jaeger, (Jaeger 1982, 204-205), convex rectangular plaques exist as early as the 18th dynasty, but became popular only under the Ramessid Period. Their terminus ad quem is problematic. They are clearly attested during the 21st dynasty, till Siamun reign (986–967 BC). However, several pieces of evidence, from Matmar cemetery (Brunton 1948, pl. LXII, 1, 5-6 - mainly 8th-7th century BC) and Naukratis itself, point towards an even later date. Since the decoration on the Naukratis plaques finds more parallels in the Ramesside Period, Jaeger suggested that they probably belong to this early period (Jaeger 1982, 205, § 1366, nn. 867-868). Brunton, G. 1948, Matmar, London. Jaeger, B. 1982. Essai de classification et datation des scarabées Menkhéperrê. Fribourg. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 156)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OB.03) (phase 3)
